Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loA. term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09%, and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy vegetable seeds to cultivate.

loans.name: Kim

texts.en: Kim N., 38, is married and lives with her husband in Kampong Cham Province, where she earns about $3 each day selling rice. Her husband, pictured here, is a musician earning $6 per day. This couple has four children, two employed as garment factory workers and two attending school. To reduce transportation costs, Mrs. Kim N. is requesting a loan to purchase a motorbike for her husband.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for transportation.

loans.name: Khoen

texts.en: Mrs. Khoen K. is a villager in Ta Daul village in Kandal province. She is a pig breeder. Since her pig-breeding business is doing well, she wants to expand it by purchasing two more pigs for breeding to earn more income. Her husband, Mr. Roup Ra, shown on the left in the photo, is a hard-working man. Mrs. Khoen K. is a 38-year-old mother whose child attends the local school.

loans.use: Purchase two more pigs for breeding to earn more income.

loans.name: Abdurozik

texts.ru: Носиров Абдурозик  1957 года рождения женат имеет 4 детей. Сотрудничает  с Микроинвест  с 2008 года.  Бизнес торговля печками.По настоящее время  был сезон торговли печек, его жена также помогает  в бизнесе, она предложила ему новый вид бизнеса так как спрос на печки только в зимний период , а весной можно начать торговлю женской одежды. Дети  помогают в бизнесе  родителям. Также он работает в TOYOTA –CENTRE имеет заработную плату, что помогает поддерживать стабильность дохода в семье.
texts.en:
Abdurozik N. was born in 1957, is married, and has four children. He has been working with MicroInvest since 2008. He sells heaters. It is currently the season to sell heaters. His wife also helps with the business. She has suggested to him that they should expand into another type of business since there is only demand for heaters in winter. They can start selling women’s clothing in the spring. The children help their parents with the business. He also works at TOYOTA–CENTRE, and his wages help maintain a stable income for the family.

Translated from Russian by Melissa Kniazeva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: for business expansion

loans.name: Ustobobo

texts.ru: Устобобо женат, ему 39 лет, имеет  3 детей. Сотрудничать начал в этом году, обратиться в Микроинвест посоветовали друзья. Раньше он работал на стройке , но такая тяжелая работа, которую предлагают только летом или когда тёплая погода, ему не по душе. Сейчас он торгует конфетами и другими сладостями на рынке г. Худжанда. Реализация проходит хорошо, он планирует кредитоваться и в дальнейшем.
texts.en:
Ustobobo is 39, married, and has three children. He began working with MicroInvest this year following the advice of friends. Earlier he worked in construction, but it is very hard work which is only available in the summer or when the weather is warm. He did not enjoy it. Now he sells candy and other sweets in the city market in Khujand. His sales are good, so he plans to get financing now and in the future.

Translated from Russian by Melissa Kniazeva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: for business expansion

loans.name: Thi Nga's Group

texts.vi:
Nguyễn Thị Nga sinh năm 1948, ( Mã số: 010103040018). Hiện chị đang sống cùng vợ chồng người con trai lớn. Gia đình chị có 6 người. Con dâu đi chợ hoa quả, con trai chị làm nghề xe ôm, 3 cháu nội còn nhỏ . Chị chủ yếu ở nhà làm nông nghiệp, chăn nuôi. Chu kỳ vay vốn này, chị vay mức vốn: 4.142.000 VND để đầu tư chăn nuôi gà. Là người có uy tín, lại tháo vát, nhanh nhẹn nên chị được bầu làm nhóm trưởng nhóm vay gồm có:
 Chử Thị Hằng sinh năm 1982, ( Mã số: 010103040019) gia đình chị có 1 cửa hàng bán sơn. Thu nhập bình quân của gia đình khoảng 4.500.000 VND. Chị tham gia vay mức vốn: 4.142.000 VND để kinh doanh sơn.
 Nguyễn Thị M. sinh năm 1967, ( Mã số: 010103040023 ). Gia đình chị chủ yếu làm nông nghiệp, chăn nuôi. Hàng ngày chị vẫn đi làm thuê ( đi phụ xây). Chị tham gia mức vay: 4.142.000 VND để đầu tư chăn nuôi gà.
 Phạm Thị V. sinh năm 1947, ( Mã số: 010103040022 ). Chị là công nhân đã về hưu có lương ổn định theo tháng khoảng 2.500.000 VND. Chị tham gia vay mức vốn: 4.142.000 VND để chăn nuôi gà.
texts.en:
Mrs. N. T. Nga (ID No: 010103040018), born in 1948, currently lives with her eldest son's family. There are 6 persons in her family. Her daughter-in-law sells fruits and vegetables in the market; her son is a driver for hire; her 3 grandchildren are still very young. Mrs. Nga mainly stays at home to perform agriculture tasks and raise livestock. This time, she would like to borrow 4,142,000VND to raise chickens. A responsible and nimble woman, she was trusted to be the group leader. Her group also consists of:
  • Mrs. Chu T. H. (ID No: 010103040019), born in 1982. Her family has a store selling paints. Her family's average monthly income is about 4,500,000VND. She would like to borrow 4,142,000VND to buy and sell paints.
  • Mrs. N. T. M. (ID No: 010103040023), born in 1967. Her family mainly does farming and raising livestock. Everyday, she also works as a builder assistant. She would like to borrow 4,142,000VND to raise chickens.
  • Mrs. Pham T. V. (ID No: 010103040022), born in 1947. She is a retiree with a stable monthly income of 2,500,000VND. She would like to borrow 4,142,000VND to raise chickens.

    • Translated from Vietnamese by Yen Thanh Pham, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Raising chickens

loans.name: Komilhuja

texts.en:
Thirty-year-old S. Komilhuja lives in the B.Gafurov region of Tajikistan but works in Khujand at the ‘Panjshanbe” bazaar, where he sells meat products (sausages and salami), sour milk products (pasteurized milk, curd, kefir and mask), vegetable oil, sweets, candies, and bread. He brings the goods from Istaravshan and Uzbekistan and also works with suppliers from Russia.

Komilhuja, a married father of three, is working hard to achieve a bright future for his children. He is now requesting a loan of Komilhuja 1200 TJ S for four months to purchase ice cream, a popular seasonal treat. Komilhuja thanks KIVA for its support and financial help.

loans.use: To purchase ice cream for his business.

loans.name: Muhabbat

texts.en: U. Muhabbat is 31 years old. She is married with 2 children She lives in the B.Gafurov region of Tajikistan but she comes every day to Khujand from Istaravshan to sell her food products in the local bazaar. She sells meat products (sausages and salami), dairy products (pasteurized milk, curd, kefir and mask), vegetable oil, sweets, candies, bread, salt and juices. Muhabbat wants to open a specialized mini-market and works very hard towards that goal. She would like to increase the variety of products that she sells and thereby increase her  profits. Muhabbat requests through KIVA a business development loan of  1200 STJ for 4 months to purchase new food products to increase her business. Muhabbat thanks KIVA for its support and financial help.

loans.use: To buy a variety of food products for resale

loans.name: Sadorat

texts.en: E. Sadorat has been a client of MicroInvest since 2007.  She would like to take out an individual loan. She has never missed a loan payment and she has been recommended as a reliable client.  Sadorat is presently engaged in selling gold jewelery. Sadorat has been in the gold jewelery selling business for 5 years. She would like to start working with wholesalers who sell gold fabrics imported from Turkey. She is applying for the business development loan of 2000 STJ for 6 months to open a gold fabric selling outlet in one of crowded local bazaars. Sadorat thanks KIVA and all its supporters..

loans.use: to open a gold fabric selling outlet

loans.name: Farhod

texts.ru:
Фарход  Каюмов  1975 года рождения, он разведен ,имеет  одного ребенка.Сотрудничает  Микроинвест 2 года. Ему необходим кредит для развития своего бизнеса. Ведь у него есть два вида бизнеса. Родители не работают, вот ему и надо как то выкручиваться.
 Он печет лепешки и реализует с со своей пекарни. Лепешки у него покупают и на рынок и для свадеб.  Он также продает кирпичи, сам лепит жжет в печи и продает.
texts.en:
Farhod K. was born in 1975, is divorced, and has one child. He has worked with MicroInvest for two 2 years. He needs a loan to develop his business. He has two businesses. His parents do not work, so he must find a way to make a living. He bakes flat breads and sells them from the bakery. He sells his flat bread at the market and for weddings. He also sells bricks which he molds himself and fires in his furnace.

Translated from Russian by Melissa Kniazeva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase flour

loans.name: Jannatoi

texts.en: Jannatoi O. lives in the Mastcho region of Tajikistan. She works in the local bazaar where she sells gold jewelery. She works with customers who wants to buy jewelery and suppliers who bring import  it from Turkey. Jannatoi is engaged in the gold jewelery business for 5 years. She is applying for a business development loan of 3000 STJ for 4 months to open an outlet in one of crowed local bazaars. Jannatoi thanks KIVA and its supporters for their hard work.

loans.use: To open a jewelery outlet in one of crowed local bazaars

loans.name: Thi Thoa's Group

texts.vi:
Đỗ Thị Thoa sinh năm 1978, ( Mã số: 010103040024 ), Chị thường mua bán gạo phục vụ người dân. Chị tham gia vay mức: 2.436.000 VND để mua thóc về xay xát thành gạo đem bán.
 Nguyễn Thị Thủy sinh năm 1983, ( Mã số: 010103040020 ). Chị làm thợ may, có thu nhập theo ngày khoảng 100.000 VND / ngày. Chị vay: 2.436.000 VND để chăn nuôi gà.
texts.en:
• Mrs. D. T. Thoa (ID No: 010103040024), born in 1978, buys and sells rice to other villagers. She would like to borrow 2,436,000VND to purchase rice to husk and sell.
  • Mrs. Nguyen T. T. (ID No: 010103040020), born in 1983, is a seamstress. Her average daily income is 100,000VND. She would like to borrow 2,436,000VND to raise chickens.

    • Translated from Vietnamese by Yen Thanh Pham, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing rice

loans.name: Mukimjon

texts.ru: Мукимжон Турсунов еще не женат, ему 22 года. С Микроинвест сотрудничает  больше восьми лет. Он торгует в аптеке лекарствами, и необходимыми медикаментами.Ему нравиться  эта работа он помогает людям в основном старикам  консультировать  им о каждом лекарстве отдельно.  Он берет кредит для приобретения медикаментов в аптеку. Родители хотят , что бы по скорей женился, но твердит что когда достаточно будет зарабатывать и "встанет на ноги", тогда он будет готов создавать семью. Он благодарен Микроинвест и кредит от КИВА, что поддержали его.
texts.en:
Mukimjon T. is single and 22 years old. He has been working with MicroInvest for several years. He sells medicines and medical supplies in a drugstore. He likes his work. He helps people, mostly the elderly, when he consults with them about their medicines. He is taking out a loan in order to acquire medicines for the drugstore. His parents want him to marry soon, but he insists that when he starts earning enough to "stand on his own two feet" then he will be ready to start a family. He is grateful to MicroInvest and Kiva for their support.

Translated from Russian by Melissa Kniazeva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Expansion

loans.name: Thi Lan's Group

texts.vi:
Chử Thị Lan sinh năm 1954. ( Mã số: 010105030012) Chồng chị đã mất, các con đã lớn và xây dựng gia đình thỉnh thoảng mới về thăm nom. Chị hiện đang sống cùng hai đứa cháu ngoại đang độ tuổi đi học. Chị có nghề đan chổi tre có thu nhập theo ngày, thu nhập bình quân của chị khoảng 2.000.000 VND/tháng. Chị vay mức vốn vay: 4.142.000 VND để mua tre về làm chổi. Chị là nhóm trưởng nhóm vay vốn gồm có: 
 Chử Thị H. sinh năm 1970,( Mã số: 010105030013)  chị vay mức vốn 4.142.000 VND để mua tre làm chổi nan.
 Trần Thị Tẩy sinh năm 1958 ( Mã số: 0101050300114 ) Chị cũng có nghề phụ là làm chổi, chị vay mức:4.142.000 VND để mua tre về làm chổi.
 Vũ Thị Yên sinh năm 1955. ( Mã số: 010105030018 )  Chị vay mức vốn: 4.142.000 VND để mua tre về đan chổi. Thu nhập bình quân của gia đình chị khoảng 2.000.000 VND/tháng.
 Nguyễn Thị Hà sinh năm 1977. ( Mã số: 010105030017 )  Gia đình chị có cửa hàng ăn sang, thu nhập bình quân khoảng 2.500.000 VND. Chị vay mức vốn: 4.142.000 VND để đầu tư cửa hàng.
 Cao Thị Nguyệt sinh năm 1982 , ( Mã số: 010105030016 )  chị làm ngề đan chổi tre, tham gia mức vốn: 3.270.000 VND để mua tre về đan chổi.
 Bùi Thị Lâm sinh năm 1962, ( Mã số: 010105030015)  chị làm thuê có thu nhập, thu nhập bình quân của gia đình khoảng: 2.000.000 VND. Chị vay mức vốn: 3.270.000 VND để chăn nuôi gà.
texts.en:
Mrs. C. T. Lan (ID No: 010105030012), as born in 1954. Her husband passed away and her children have their own families so they only visit her once in a while. She currently stays with her two young grandchildren. She makes brooms for a living with a daily income. Her average monthly income is 2 millions VND. She would like to borrow 4,142,000VND to buy bamboos to make brooms. She is the group leader of a group consisting of:
  • Mrs. C. T. H. (ID No: 010105030013), born in 1970. She would like to borrow 4,142,000VND to purchase bamboo to make brooms.
  • Mrs. Tran T. T. (ID No: 0101050300114), born in 1958. She would like to borrow 4,142,000VND to purchase bamboo to make brooms.
  • Mrs. Vu T. Y. (ID No: 010105030018), born in 1955.She would like to borrow 4,142,000VND to purchase bamboo to make brooms. Her family's iaverage monthly income is 2 millions VND.
  • Mrs. NguY. T. H. (ID No: 010105030017), born in 1977. Her family has a breakfast eatery with a monthly income of 2,500,000VND. She would like to borrow 4,142,000VND to invest in her eatery.
  • Mrs. Cao T. N. (ID No: 010105030016), born in 1982. She would like to borrow 3,270,000VND to purchase bamboo to make brooms.
  • Mrs. Bui T. L. (ID No: 010105030015), born in 1962. She is a worker for hire, with an average monthly income of 2 millions VND. She would like to borrow 3,270,000VND to rear chickens.

    • Translated from Vietnamese by Y. Thanh Pham, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: making bamboo brooms

loans.name: Saadat

texts.en: Saadat is a baker and has been in this business for 3 years.  She is 37, married, and has 2 children.  She needs a loan of $1200 so she can buy flour and other supplies.  With this loan Saadat can increase her business and add to her income.

loans.use: to buy flour and other supplies for baking bread

loans.name: Abdugafor

texts.en:
Abdugafor is 35 years old, married, and has one son. He has been a vegetable farmer for five years. This is something he does well and what he likes most. For Abdugafor, there is nothing better than being in touch with nature and watching his crops grow year after year. Abdugafor also raises cattle with the help of his family. Now he wants to borrow money to purchase seeds and fertilizer for the vegetable growing season. This is the first loan Abdugafor has requested from IMON International.  He promises to repay the loan without any violations and thanks all lenders for their support.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road; the end of Alexander the Great's rule; and with it’s famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets as: Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC.  And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. 
But, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics.  The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy.  In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable.  These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia.  While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. 

IMON's History
Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchase seed and fertilizer

loans.name: Umri

texts.ru: Умри 36 летняя женщина, мать двоих детей,муж работает мастером по ремонту телевизоров.Сама Умри работает техничкой в больнице "Нур".До обеда она заканчивает свою работу и выходит на торговлю.Её заработная плата не хватает для проживания, поэтому Умри имеет бизнес по продаже продуктов питания.Товар ей привозят сами оптовики поставщики.Кредит Умри хочет использовать для закупа макаронных изделий и другого товара первой необходимости для населения.
texts.en:
Umri is 36 and the mother of two children. Her husband works as a TV repairman. Umri works as a technician in Noor Hospital. She finishes her work before lunch and then goes to the market to trade. Her salary is not enough to live off; therefore, Umri is in business selling food. She buys her goods from wholesalers. Umri wants to take out a loan in order to buy pasta and other goods local residents need.

Translated from Russian by Melissa Kniazeva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying food

loans.name: Islomidin

texts.en:
Islomidin supports and provides for his loved ones as a farmer through hard work and dedication.  He leaves home every day at dawn to work on his farm and to look after his cattle.  He would like to expand his business, but he needs a loan in order to purchase young cattle and the fodder to feed them. He will cherish the memory of all those who gave him a helping hand when he needed it.

Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchase cattle and fodder

loans.name: Riski

texts.en:
A. Riski is 46 years old and a widow with two children. She sells women’s shawls in the central market of Shahrituz and her business has been successful for 15 years. Riski’s sales are the main source of her income which allows her to improve the living conditions in her home and to provide her children with education. She requests $1000 to purchase more shawls in order to increase the range of goods she offers for sale. Riski would like to thank everyone for supporting her and promises to pay off the loan on time.

loans.use: Purchase more women's shawls to sell

loans.name: Abdurahim

texts.ru: Молодой человек 22 лет , не женат,Абдурахим  бизнесмен на рынке "Рохи Абрешим". Абдурахим самостоятельно занимается бизнесом продажи колбасных изделий. Он закупает с колбасных цехов оптом разных сортов колбасы и продаёт их в розницу ,в развес.У него качественный товар , поэтому у него свои постоянные клиенты с районов , которые покупают у него большими партиями.Для увеличения своего оборотного капитала Абдурахим решил взять кредит.
texts.en:
Abdurahim is a 22 year old bachelor and an entrepreneur working at the Rohi Abreshim market, where he runs his own business selling sausage. The sausage is bought wholesale from factories and sold at retail price by weight. His high quality meat attracts regular customers from outside the city who buy large quantities. Abdurahim decided to request a loan in order to expand his working capital.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Meats

loans.name: Bahri

texts.en:
Problems and money shortages have never defeated Bahri, who has always looked for a way to get past obstacles and to improve her situation. Bahri is an extremely hard-working and energetic woman. She is 38 years old, married, and the loving mother of four children. Bahri started her own business because her husband’s salary was not enough to cover their family’s expenses. For more than 10 years, she has operated a store where she sells children’s clothing. Her store is well-known, and people love to visit because it's clean, tidy, and run by someone who is very kind and thoughtful. Bahri hopes that her store will keep growing so that she can maintain a comfortable life for her family, especially for her children. To make that possible, she has applied for a new loan in the amount of $1000 that she will use to buy more clothing to sell. She promises to repay the loan in time and thanks everyone for supporting her.

loans.use: Purchase more clothing to sell.

loans.name: Umriniso

texts.en:
Umriniso M. is 37 years old. She is married with 4 children. Umriniso sells foodstuffs and detergents. She rents a place for selling which is located in one of the local markets. Umriniso has been running her own small business together with her husband (pictured) for 4 years. The income she derives allows her to provide for family expenses. Umriniso works very hard to give her dearest children a good education and to make them happy. Thus, today she requests $ 600 USD. Umriniso thanks everyone for support and promises to pay the loan in time.

loans.use: Purchasing foodstuffs to increase the range of goods.

loans.name: Them

texts.en: Them S., 64, is married and lives with her husband in the Kampong Cham province. She and her husband are rice farmers and typically make about US $2 every day. This couple also gets support from two of their children who are construction workers. Mrs. Them S. would like to take out a loan of US $400 to raise pigs for extra profit.

loans.use: to purchase pigs

loans.name: Hurmat

texts.en:
Hurmat S. is a hardworking and responsible widowed woman with two adult children. To support herself and her children, Hurmat has worked selling Tajik national dresses for women in a roving market. From that job, she makes money for her home. These activities have also permitted her to make time available to be with her children. Life hasn't been easy for Hurmat, as she now carries the responsibility for her family alone, but her love for her children motivated her to get ahead. To increase her sales, Hurmat requests a loan of $ 800 USD, which she will use to buy merchandise that is on sale and which she will use to sell at a special price to her customers. This will allow her to grow her customer base. You can be an important enabler of Hurmat's accomplishments. She needs your help to grow her business and improve the quality of her living.

loans.use: Purchase Tajik national dresses for women in order to increase the range of goods for selling.

loans.name: Makole E Group

texts.en:
Angelina has been a bites (snacks) seller in the Ipagala neighborhood of Dodoma for 1 year. She currently earns an average monthly profit of $125. Every day she works at her business for 12 hours.  She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more materials for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profits will increase and she will be able to grow her business and pay school fees for her children.  


Angelina is 36 years old, married, and has two children: ages 16 and 6.  She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group members, Pasisi and Maria. Each woman also has her own small business in Dodoma.

loans.use: To buy more materials for her business.

loans.name: Mairam

texts.en:
Mairam K. is a mother with a great desire to get ahead in life. Her great spirit, strong will and hard work have allowed her to improve her quality of life and that of her family. For the past 10 years, this persevering lady has been working very hard raising and selling cattle. With the income she generates, she provides a better quality of life for her children, who are her greatest joy for her. She asks for a $1000 USD loan with the term of 12 months in order to buy more young cattle to later sell when they are fully grown. With this investment, Mairam will be able to substantially grow her earnings and improve her quality of life. Let’s support this dedicated mother's proposal.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International:

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. Its history also includes famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets such as Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others.

The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And even today it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still lives in abject poverty.

IMON's History 

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low-income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing young cattle in order to expand the business and to improve the living conditions of the family.

loans.name: Makole E Group

texts.en:
Catherine has owned a small shop in the Ipagala neighborhood of Dodoma for 2 years. She currently earns an average monthly profit of $225. Every day she works at her business for 12 hours.  She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more items for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profits will increase and she will be able to grow her business and pay school fees for her children.  


Catherine is 41 years old, married, and has four children between the ages of 21 and 13.  She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group member, Mary, who also has her own small business in Dodoma.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business.

loans.name: Nazokat

texts.en:
K. Nazokat is a 54-year-old woman. Nazokat and her husband have been married for almost 30 years and raised three wonderful children. Two of them are already married and have children of their own who adore their grandparents. Nazokat has been running her own small business for 7 years already; she has a store where she sells shampoo, detergent, toothpaste, brushes, and other items. Her youngest daughter helps her in the storeat the register and serving clients. Nazokat and her daughter are very friendly and polite, which allows them to gain more clientele. Now she is requesting for $1000 US dollars. Nazokat is planning to spend the loan to purchase more goods to sell, thus increasing the range of her products. Nazokat promises to pay her loan within 6 months and thanks everybody who decides to support her.

It was the home of famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets as: Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC.  And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. 

But, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics.  The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy.  In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable.  These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia.  While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. 

IMON's History

Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To increase the variety and volume of items to sell in the business

loans.name: Mehyeddin

texts.en: Mehyeddin was born in 1983. He lives in the Khachmaz region, in the Murshud Oba village. He is single. Two years ago he started a farming business. Now this young man needs a loan of 950 AZN to buy fertilizer and seedlings to improve his farming business.

loans.use: to buy  fertilizer and seedlings for his farm

loans.name: Kayumjon

texts.en:
S. Kayumjon is 50 years old. He is married with three children. Kayumjon is the sole breadwinner for his family and his only income comes from the cultivation and sale of large livestock at the local market. 

Every year, he buys young heifers from the farms in adjacent villages. He raises them with the help of his wife and children and then sells the adult cows and bulls to local butchers. Today Kayumjon is thinking about expanding his business, since the income from his present herd isn't enough to provide for his family. He plans to purchase additional young cattle. To do this, he needs to invest an additional $1,200 in his business. In order to receive this amount, Savridin has applied for a loan from Kiva's partner organization, IMON International.   

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road; the end of Alexander the Great's rule; and its famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, such as Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC.  And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.
 
But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia.  While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. 

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low-income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing cattle in order to expand the business

loans.name: Chhin

texts.en: Chhin S. N., 27, is married with one young child living at home in the Kampong Cham province. She is a rice farmer, typically making US$1 a day; her husband grows vegetables. Her husband typically makes about US$2 a day. Chhin S. N. would like a loan of US$1200 to purchase a grinding mill so that she can rent this machine to the local farmers and earn additional money to help raise her family.

loans.use: purchase a grinding mill

loans.name: Soun

texts.en: Soun S. P., 37, is married with five young children living at home in the Kampong Cham province. She works as a farmer, typically making US$1 a day. Her husband, Moun Soa, is a construction worker who typically makes about US$4 a day. Soun S. P. would like a loan of US$1000 to purchase a trailer and build a stand to sell vegetables at the market. She believes that these purchases will allow her to increase her income and be able to better support her large family.

loans.use: to purchase a trailer and build a vegetable stand

loans.name: Seng

texts.en: Seng K., 60, is a widow living in the Kampong Cham province with her only child. To earn a living, she sells traditional medicine and makes US$4 per day. She is also supported by her child who works in the garment factory. Seng K. is asking for a loan of US$500 to purchase more traditional medicine to sell. She believes this opportunity will enable her to raise her standard of living.

loans.use: to purchase medicine for resale

loans.name: Sem

texts.en: Sem S., 53, is a widowed rice farmer who lives in the Kampong Cham province with two of her children. She typically makes US$2 each day and is supported economically by some of her children. Her children are the biggest source of her income and she wants to take out a loan to aid them with their expenses. With a loan of US$700 from CREDIT, Sem S. wants to purchase blacksmith materials for her children.

loans.use: To purchase blacksmith materials

loans.name: Eng

texts.en: Eng S., 49, is married and lives in the Kampong Cham province with her husband and five children. She work as a rice farmer and a recycler, making around US$5 a day. Her husband makes around US$3 a day selling utensils. Inflation has caused prices to soar in Cambodia and recent hikes in oil and rice prices have caused financial struggles for many Cambodians. Looking for ways to increase her income and combat rising expenses, Eng S. has asked CREDIT for a loan of US$700 to purchase a motorbike and utensils.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike and utensils

loans.name: Lorn

texts.en:
Lorn C., 44, is married and resides with her husband in Kampong Cham province. She is a rice miller and makes around US$ 2.50 every day. Her husband is a construction foreman and is able to earn US$ 8 per day. This couple has six children, two of whom are construction workers and two who are in school.

Mrs. Lorn C. would like to take out a loan to purchase a rice mill and a stock of rice so that she can take off rice husks with the intention of re-selling the rice and turning a profit. She is confident that this will be a good business venture and sees it as a tool to increase her income and raise her family's standard of living.

loans.use: buying rice and rice mill

loans.name: Ek

texts.en:
Ek C. is 33 years old and lives with her husband in Kampong Cham, Cambodia. She has been growing and selling vegetables since 2006 to earn a living and is able to make US$ 2 every day, while her husband, pictured here, works as a moto-taxi driver. On average he makes US$ 4 per day. This couple has two children and both of them are in school.

Mrs. Ek C. would like to take out a loan to replace an old and unreliable motorbike for her husband. The old one needs many repairs and uses a lot of gas when operating.

loans.use: motorbike

loans.name: Chea

texts.en:
Chea N. is 49 years old and lives with her husband in Kampong Cham province. She works as a farmer and typically makes US$ 3 per day. Her husband is a moto-taxi driver and earns about US$ 2 every day in profit. This couple has five children, four of whom are married and live separately.

Mrs. Chea N. would like to take out a loan to hire farm workers to plant bananas.

loans.use: hiring workers to plant bananas

loans.name: Khoin

texts.en:
KhO. O., 29, is married and lives with her husband in Kampong Cham, Cambodia. She and her husband are farmers and recyclers and typically make a combined US$ 5 every day. This couple has three children, two of whom are enrolled in school and one who is too young to attend school.

Mrs. KhO. O. would like to take out a loan to purchase a motorbike as well as utensils to re-sell.

loans.use: motorbike and utensils

loans.name: Touch

texts.en:
Touch H. is 40 years old and resides with her husband in Kampong Cham province. She grows and sells rice and also has a business as a recycler. On average, she makes about US$ 1.50 in profit every day. Her husband sells utensils to earn a living and is able to make US$ 10 in revenue each day.

This couple has one child who is already married. Mrs. Touch H. is asking for a loan to purchase more utensils for her husband.

loans.use: purchase utensils to re-sell

loans.name: Khiev

texts.en:
Khiev Y., 41, is married and lives with five of her children in Kampong Cham province. She and her husband are farmers who typically make about US$ 1 each day and are supported in part by two children working in a garment factory.

The weather conditions have been difficult for farming in Cambodia this past year and inflation has also been out of control. These factors have played into a difficult economic year for many Cambodians, Khiev Y. included. In light of these economic difficulties, she is asking for a loan of US$ 250 to purchase fertilizer and repair her house. She is confident that this loan will allow her to increase her daily income and to better support her family.

loans.use: fertilizer and home repairs

loans.name: Teo

texts.en:
Teo Y. S. is 56 years old and lives with her husband in Kampong Cham province. She and her husband are farmers and work digging wells in the village. On average, they make a combined US$ 5 in profit a day. This couple has three children, one of whom is a waiter and two are in school.

Mrs. Teo Y. S. is asking for a loan to purchase digging tools.

loans.use: digging tools

loans.name: Huon's Group

texts.en:
This group of borrowers consists of five members. Its leader, H., 41, has two children: both of them are attending school. She is married to Thy, 42, who is a local farmer, planting crops in a big field inherited from his parents. H. has been a local wine distiller since 2000. She always buys the paddy rice from farmers to stock her stall in bulk. She is a struggling mother and a responsible neighbor.

To help meet the family's needs, H. is also raising piglets in her pigpen behind her house because the leftovers after distilling can be made into pig feed. Recently, H. plans to have another pigpen for her pig-raising so she is looking for a loan to buy more piglets for her pigpen.

The other four members are:

H., 46, who earns a living selling fish and is looking for a loan to buy a motorbike for transport;

H., 35, who has a battery-recharging service and is taking out a loan to buy a motorbike for her business;

C., 29, who plants vegetables and is taking out a loan to buy fertilizer for her vegetables;

and P., 37, who owns a grocery store and is taking out a loan to buy more cooked ingredients for her store.

They are all living in Siem Reap Province.

loans.use: To buy more piglets for her pig pen

loans.name: Penh's Group

texts.en:
This group loan is made up of four members, all residents of Meanchey Commune, Siem Reap Province, Cambodia. Its leader, K., 34 years old, owns farmland for cultivating rice and vegetable crops. She has specialized in this since 2000, currently earning an average of US$ 2 a day.

To help cater a little more for the family’s food needs, her husband is working building houses. The family is very responsible for their three children; all of them are single and attend school.

K. is requesting a loan to purchase a motorcycle for the family to ride. The other three borrowers are:

D., who grows vegetables as well as raising pigs near her home and is asking for a loan to buy piglets to raise;

H., who is a grocery seller and wants a loan to purchase a fishing boat for a fishing business; and

N. who grows vegetables and also sells groceries and wants a loan to buy fertilizer for her crops.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle for the family

loans.name: Sixbeltha's Group

texts.en:
Sixbeltha has been a fish seller in the Ipagala neighborhood of Dodoma for 3 years. She currently earns an average monthly profit of US$ 175. Every day she works at her business for 8 hours. She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more fish for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business and save money for future use.

Sixbeltha is 40 years old, married, and has six children: aged between 25 and 8. She also cares for one additional dependent. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group members: Doto, Thabita, Veronika, and Maria. Each woman has her own small business in Dodoma.

loans.use: To buy more fish for re-sale in order to expand her business

loans.name: M/mpya G Group

texts.en:
Catherine has been a tailor in the Ipagala neighborhood of Dodoma for three years. She currently earns an average monthly profit of $125. Every day she works at her business for 12 hours.  She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more tailoring items for her business. She is hopping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business and save money for future use.  

Catherine is  25 years old and single. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group members, Amina, Helena, and Josephina. Each woman has her own small business in Dodoma.

loans.use: To buy tailoring supplies

loans.name: Dourng

texts.en: E. is 60 years old and a resident of SiE. Reap Province. She has six children: five of thE. are married and live separately, and the other one owns a small grocery store and lives with her. E. is a widow, and she has been a primary school teacher since 1990. She is a struggling mother and a responsible neighbor. She lives in a small house with a small kitchen. Because her house is located near a resort place, E. wants to increase her daughter's business. So E. is looking for a loan of $400 to buy more cooked ingredients for her daughter's business. The loan will help the family have a better standard of living. This is a picture of E. and her daughter.

loans.use: To buy more cooked ingredients

loans.name: Yin

texts.en: Yin S., 55, is a widow who lives with her seven children in Phnom Penh, Cambodia. She sells meatballs and typically makes USD $3 every day. Three of her daughters are garment factory workers and each makes USD $2 per day. The rest of her children are in school. Mrs. Yin S. would like a loan to purchase more meatballs to sell.

loans.use: To purchase meatballs

loans.name: M/mpya G Group

texts.en:
Zuhura has owned a small beauty salon in the Ipagala neighborhood of Dodoma for one year.  She currently earns an average monthly profit of $175. Every day she works at her business for 12 hours.  She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more salon items for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business and save money for future use.  

Zuhura is 21 years old, married, and has a two-year-old child. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group members, Jesca and Esther. Each woman also has her own small business in Dodoma.

loans.use: To buy salon items

loans.name: Fariz

texts.en: Fariz was born in 1986. He is single. This young man lives in Khachmaz town. Two years ago, he started a furniture making business. Now he needs a loan of 950 AZN to buy the necessary materials for improving furniture making.

loans.use: to buy the necessary materials for improving furniture making

loans.name: Chadulu O Group

texts.en:
Hadija has been a charcoal seller in the Ipagala neighborhood of Dodoma for 10 years. She currently earns an average monthly profit of $25. Every day she works at her business for 12 hours. She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more charcoal for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.

Hadija is married and has four children between the ages of 2 and 13. She also cares for one additional dependent. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group members: Raila, Kuruthum and Tune. Each woman also has her own small business in Dodoma.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal for her business.

loans.name: Pen

texts.en: Pen C., 61, is a soldier earning $3 a day. His wife and seven children work at home making brooms, and together they average $3 a day. Pen C. would like to take out a loan to buy more grass so that his family can make more brooms to sell at the market.  (Pen C.’s wife is pictured with some of their children.)

loans.use: To purchase grass for making brooms.

loans.name: Bee

texts.en: Bee S. K. is 56 years old and has a business operating a moto-taxi, with which he makes $10 every day. His wife is a nanny and earns $1 per day. This couple has five children, two of whom are garment factory workers and two who are in school. Bee S. K. would like to take out a loan to purchase a trailer to attach to his motorbike.

loans.use: Purchase a trailer.

loans.name: Chhay

texts.en: S. is 36 years old and lives in Siem Reap Province. She has three children, all of whom are single and live with her. Her older daughter is employed as a garment worker, which adds to the family's income. S. is married to Nginh, 32, who is a local construction foreman with a net income of $3 a day. S. grows vegetables behind her house and has sold her gourds in bulk since 2003. She also sells fish at the market that she gathers in bulk from a fisherman. Her sales have increased her family’s income. However, S. now faces difficulties with transportation and with the condition of her garden soil. She is looking for a loan of $600 to buy a motorbike and fertilizer, which will help her out with her business, and will help the family reach a better standard of living.

loans.use: Buy a motorbike and fertilizer.

loans.name: Tak

texts.en: Tak L. is 26 years old and lives in Phnom Penh, Cambodia with her sister. She earns a living by selling boiled and roasted corn at the market and makes $5 every day. Her sister helps with the income working at a garment factory earning $2 a day. Tak L. would like to take out a loan so that she can buy more corn to sell.

loans.use: To purchase corn.

loans.name: Tes

texts.en: S., 45, lives in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia, where she earns a living selling porridge at her house. For additional income she grows vegetables such as cucumbers, pumpkins and potatoes. She is a widow with five children, all of whom are single. Two of her sons are employed as construction workers. S. is asking for a loan to use as capital to enlarge her investment in her porridge business so that she can increase sales. Because her sons need a bicycle for traveling to work, she would also like to buy a bicycle for them.

loans.use: To enlarge her investment selling porridge and to buy a bicycle for her children to ride to work

loans.name: Ouch

texts.en:
Ouch S., 65, is married and resides with her husband in Phnom Penh, Cambodia. She runs a grocery store, making around US$ 5 per day, while her husband earns US$ 10 by working as a village chief. This couple has five children, four of whom are married and live separately, and one who is a high school teacher.

Ouch S. is asking for a loan to expand her grocery store by adding grocery items to meet her customers' demand. (Their oldest daughter is pictured because Mrs. Ouch and her husband were not available.)

loans.use: To expand her grocery store

loans.name: Chadulu O Group

texts.en:
Joha has been a fish seller in the Ipagala neighborhood of Dodoma for 10 years. She currently earns an average monthly profit of US$ 35. Every day she works at her business for 12 hours. She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more fish for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.

Joha is married and has two children: 25 and 18. She also cares for one additional dependent. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group member, Christina. Each woman has her own small business in Dodoma.

loans.use: To buy more fish for re-sale in order to expand her business

loans.name: Irenea

texts.en:
Irenea is 47 years old and her business is hog fattening. She was in the business when she got married, but it stopped. As a widowed woman she needs to double her time in the business to give her children the best. Her initial loan from ASHI will be her starting capital to establish this business again.

She worked as cook in her neighborhood for additional income to cover the daily expenses of the family. She planned to have a piggery in the future and when it generates more income, then it will help for the studies of her youngest daughter in college.

loans.use: purchasing 2  piglets

loans.name: Gloren

texts.en:
Gloren is 36 years old, married to a driver of heavy equipment. They were blessed with 5 children, all in elementary level, who serve as her inspiration to work at her business.

She will purchase piglets to start this project: that's what she proposes to ASHI. She learned to raise pigs from her mother; that’s why she knows the process. She wants to add rice and fish-vending for extra income for resources of food and maintenance of poultry.

Gloren dreams of having a piggery someday as her source of income in sending children to school until they finish their studies.

loans.use: purchasing piglets, a sack of rice, and fish

loans.name: Rouen

texts.en:
S. is 30 years old and a resident of Siem Reap Province. She has three children; all of them are students. She is married to Duch, 28, who is a local construction foreman with a net income of US$ 3. S. has owned a grocery store for more than two years and she can earn US$ 4 per day.

In her store, she also sells gasoline retail to the commune. She is a struggling mother and a responsible neighbor. Recently S. has plans to increase her income from this business. So she is taking a loan of US$ 1000 to buy more products for her store and enlarge her store's building.

loans.use: To buy more products for her store and rebuild her store

loans.name: Chadulu O Group

texts.en:
Salma has owned a small food-vending store in the Ipagala neighborhood of Dodoma for 4 years. Every day she works at her business for 6 hours.  She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more food items for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.  


Salma is 48 years old, married, and has three children between the ages of 18 and 24. She also cares for two additional dependents.

She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group members: Amina, Matrona and Zakia. Each woman also has her own small business in Dodoma.

loans.use: To buy more food items for her business

loans.name: Keo

texts.en:
Keo C. is 34 years old and resides with her husband in the Kampong Chhnang province. She and her husband are fish sellers and typically earn about $50 in revenue per day combined. This couple has four children. Two of the children are in school and two are too young to attend school.

Keo C. would like to take out a loan of $500 so that she can purchase more fish to sell at the market.

loans.use: To purchase fish.

loans.name: Millicent

texts.en:
Millicent A. is a 33-year-old mother of 4 children. She is requesting a loan so that she can add more stock to her clothing shop, where she currently averages selling 8 shirts a day. She would like to purchase more stock so that she can increase her sales.

She wanted people to know that all her kids are doing well in school and that Kiva loans help people like her grow their businesses.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to sell

loans.name: Ky

texts.en: Ky K., 33, lives with her three children, all students, and her husband in Kampong Chhnang Province.  They operate a CDs and VCDs store from their home, earning around $7 daily, and they also have another business selling resin.  Ky would like to take out a loan to order more CDs and VCDs for resale and to purchase more resin.

loans.use: To purchase CDs, VCDs and resin.

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en: Sarah A. K. is a 25-year-old married mother of two, Simon Odhiambo and David Onyongo. She sells potatoes in a stall situated in Kibuye market. She plans on using the loan to purchase more sweet potatoes, which she buys from farmers in Nakuru, Kenya's fourth largest town. Both her children attend school and she will use the profits, in part, to pay their school fees.

loans.use: buying sweet potatoes

loans.name: Margret

texts.en: Margret Sienje is a 26-year-old mother of 2 children, raising them on her own. She sells clothes in the Nyamasaria slum and is looking for a small loan so she can expand her business. She hopes to improve the lives of her children and will be using her profits to pay their school fees.

loans.use: Clothing

loans.name: Nov

texts.en: Nov H. is 53 years old and lives with her husband in Kampong Cham province. She sells fermented fish at the market to earn a living and is able to make around US$ 20 in revenue each day. Her husband is a farmer who grows rice and vegetables and makes US$ 5 a day. This couple has three children, two of whom are in school and one who is a farmer. Nov H. would like to take out a loan to purchase more fermented fish to re-sell.

loans.use: purchase fish to re-sell

loans.name: Sos

texts.en: Sos M. is 28 years old and resides with her husband in Kampong Cham province. She has a grocery store, making around US$ 10 in revenue each day, while her husband earns US$ 5 per day growing and selling yams. This couple has two children and both of them are in school. Sos M. is asking for a loan so that she can add to her grocery inventory to meet her customers' demand.

loans.use: increased inventory

loans.name: Kong

texts.en: Kong S., 50, has business selling rice and making baskets to sell at the market. Her business has been around for about ten years and she makes US$ 8 every day. Her husband is village chief and earns US$ 3 a day. This couple has one son and he is a rice dealer. On average, he makes US$ 10 in revenue each day. Kong S. is asking for a loan to purchase a stock of rice and a motorbike to transport rice.

loans.use: To purchase a stock of rice and motorbike

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Grace A., a 30-year-old resident of Kisumu, has been in business for seven years selling kerosene to supplement the income of her husband, a civil servant. She is requesting a loan to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchsae kerosene for her business.

loans.name: Sos

texts.en: Sos S. is 46 years old and sells fruits in Kampong Cham province. Her business has been around for about ten years and she makes US$10 every day. Her husband is a taxi driver and earns US$8 per day. Selling fruit has been a difficult business, as there is high inflation and weather conditions that have not been conducive for a good growing season. She is asking for a loan of US$1200 to reinvest into her own fruit business and increase her stock of fruits to sell. She sees this investment as an opportunity that will be able to increase her daily income. (Sos S. is pictured in the middle)

loans.use: To reinvest in fruit business

loans.name: Sok

texts.en:
S. is 45 years old and a resident of Siem Reap Province. She has eight children: the first three are married and live separately, another one is single but living with her and employed as a local construction worker, and the last four are attending school. S. is married to Tha, 49, who is a traditional wine distiller with a net income of US$ 4 per day.

Since 1999, S. has earned a living by raising pigs in her pig pen behind her house because the leftovers from distilling in her husband's business can be made into pig feed. Her business is going well and she needs to rebuild her pig pen, so S. is applying for a loan of US$ 600 to buy a number of pigs for her pig pen and to rebuild her pig pen.

loans.use: To buy a number of pigs for her pig pen and to rebuild her pig pen

loans.name: Chadulu K Group

texts.en:
Martha has been a clothes seller in the Ipagala neighborhood of Dodoma for 7 years. She currently earns an average monthly profit of US$ 250. Every day she works at her business for 12 hours. She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more clothes for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business and to improve her home.

Martha is 40 years old, married, and has six children: aged between 24 and 5. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group members: Rose, Zainabu, Maria, and Anna. Each woman has her own small business in Dodoma.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for her business

loans.name: Kong

texts.en: Kong S. is 51years old and has a business making and selling fried bananas in his village to earn a living. She is able to make around US$9 every day, while her husband earns US$10 a day working as a farmer. He grows and sells cashew nuts for market wholesalers. This couple has four children, one of whom is a hair dresser and three who are in school. Kong S. would like to take out a loan to purchase hair dressing materials for her daughter.

loans.use: To buy hairdressing supplies

loans.name: Sok

texts.en: Sok K., 39, is married and lives with her husband in Phnom Penh, Cambodia. She works in a grocery store, making around US$4 every day. Her husband, pictured here, earns US$7 working as a motor-taxi driver. This couple has three children, two of whom are in school and one is too young to attend. Sok K. would like to take out a loan to replace an old and unreliable motorbike for her husband.

loans.use: To replace a motorbike.

loans.name: Pha

texts.en:
Pha S. N. is 25 years old and lives with her husband in the Kampong Cham province. She works in a grocery store, making about $20 in revenue every day. Her husband is a farmer and earns $2 per day. They have two young children.

Pha S. N. would like to take out a loan so that she can expand her grocery store by adding more products to meet her clients' demand.

loans.use: To increase inventory at her grocery store

loans.name: Chim

texts.en:
Chim S., 38, is married and resides with her husband in the Kampong Cham province. She is a good housewife who stays at home doing housework and cooking for her family members. Her husband is a carpenter who makes $10 in revenue every day. This couple also gets support from two children who sell duck eggs.

Mrs. Chim S. would like to ask for a loan to purchase wood for her husband to expand his carpentry business.

loans.use: To purchase wood to expand carpentry business

loans.name: Chuon

texts.en:
Choun S., 48, is a farmer who lives with her husband in the Kampong Cham province. She grows and sells rice to the market to earn a living, and is able to make about $2 every day. Besides this activity, she also weaves palm leaves. Her husband is a moto-taxi driver and earns $3 per day. This couple has two children.

Choun S. would like to take out a loan to purchase rice so that she can resell it to the villagers, earn an extra profit and raise her standard of living.

loans.use: To buy rice to resell

location.town: Tboung Kmum district, Kampong Cham province, Cambo

loans.name: Chhao

texts.en:
L. is 49 years old and a resident of Siem Reap Province. She has four children: One is married and lives separately, two are local construction workers, and the last one is attending school. L. is a widow. She sells Khmer noodles to the commune.

She is a struggling mother and a responsible neighbor. She earns a good profit from her business because she is good at cooking Khmer noodle cuisine. She uses her old traditional equipment to make Khmer noodles, but it's broken very often. So L. is applying for a loan of $100 to buy new traditional equipment to make Khmer noodles for her business. She dreams of a big house and a degree for her child.

loans.use: To buy new traditional equipment to make Khmer noodles

loans.name: San

texts.en:
San K. is a widower of three children who lives in the Kampong Cham province. He has a business charging batteries from his home to earn a living, and is able to make US$5 per day. The family also gets support from two children who work as a hairdresser and a tailor.

Mr. San K. is asking for a loan to purchase hairdressing tools for his daughter. (Hak Sreypuch, a daughter of Mr. San K., is pictured at home.)

loans.use: Hairdressing supplies for daughter

loans.name: Korng

texts.en: Korng S., 47, is a widow who lives with her two children in the Kampong Cham province. She grows and sells yams and makes US$6 every day. She is also supported by her two children who operate motor-taxi services. Mrs. Korng S. would like to take out a loan to purchase yams from farmers and resell them to market retailers.

loans.use: to purchase yams to resell

location.town: Tboung Kmum district, Kampong Cham province, Cambo

loans.name: Rous

texts.en: Rous N., 57, has a business renting rooms from her home and is able to make US$5 per day. Her husband stays at home and helps with the house work. Two of their children are wedding chefs. Rous N. would like to take out a loan to build additional rooms to rent out.

loans.use: To build more rooms to rent out

loans.name: Lach

texts.en: Lach S. is 51 years old and resides in Phnom Penh, Cambodia with two of her children. She is a professional tailor and works from her home. She is able to make about US$11 every day. One of her children is a taxi driver and makes US$3 per day. Lach S. would like to take out a loan to purchase a sewing machine to expand her tailoring business.

loans.use: To purchase sewing machine.

loans.name: Nou

texts.en: Nou T., 57, is married and resides with her husband in Kampong Cham province. She works in a grocery store, making around US$6 every day, while her husband makes US$5 a day by running a moto-taxi business. This couple has one child. Nou T. is asking for a loan to purchase yams from farmers to resell to market retailers.

loans.use: To buy yams to resell

location.town: Tboung Kmum district, Kampong Cham province, Cambo

loans.name: Kim

texts.en: Kim S., 55, is a true entrepreneur who has a business selling a chicken and rice dish from her home. On average, she makes around US$6 per day. Her husband is a farmer who grows rubber plant. He makes US$5 per day. This couple has six children, three of whom are in school and the rest helps their mother sell the chicken and rice dish. Mrs. Kim S. is asking for a loan to reinvest into her business and also to be used to create another business to help raise her family.

loans.use: To reinvest in the food business and start a new business

loans.name: Sabina's Group

texts.en:
Sabina has been a charcoal seller in the Ipagala neighborhood of Dodoma for 3 years.She currently earns an average monthly profit of $225. Every day she works at her business for 12 hours.  Sabina is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more charcoal for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to expand her business, improve her home and pay school fees for her children.  


Sabina is 38 years old, married, and has four children between the ages of 8 and 20. She also cares for two additional dependents. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group member, Asha: Who also has her own small business in Dodoma.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal for her business.

loans.name: Hem

texts.en: Hem S., 35, sells rice noodle in the Siem Reap province. Every day, she makes about US$1.5. Rice noodle is one of favorite foods among the Cambodian people. It is served with vegetables and soup. Her husband has a business selling wood and makes US$5 per day. This couple has four children, two of whom are in school and two who are construction workers. Hem S. would like to take out a loan so that she can purchase a motorbike for her husband to transport wood.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike to transport wood

loans.name: Chadulu K Group

texts.en:
Hadija has owned a small food vendor store in the Ipagala neighborhood of Dodoma for 5 years. She currently makes an average monthly profit of $175. Every day she works at her business for 12 hours.  She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more food items for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business, improve her home and pay school fees for her children.  


Hadija is 48 years old, married, and has four children between 12  and 28 years old. She also cares for one additional dependent. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group members, Nelly, Mary and Emmy.Each woman also has her own small business in Dodoma.

loans.use: To buy more food items for her business.

loans.name: Moch's Group

texts.en:
This group of borrowers consists of four members. Its leader, Moch Mom, is 46 years old and a mother of six children. Two children are married and live separately, and the other four attend school. She is a widow and sells charcoal throughout the commune. Another income of hers is renting rooms. Mrs. Mom owns a numbers of rentable rooms which are full of clients as her house is located next to the market. She is a good mother and a responsible neighbor with a net income of $ 5 per day. 

Mrs. Mom recently rented another shop for her business. She is looking for a loan to buy charcoal for her new shop. The other three members in this loan group are: N., 38, who sells traditional cakes in the market, is looking for a loan to buy more cake baking supplies. S., 47, who owns a grocery store is requesting a loan to buy a motorbike for her business. And H., 40, who sells sweets in the market is requesting a loan to invest and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy charcoal for her new shop

loans.name: Kert

texts.en: Kert N., 53, is a widow who lives with four children in the Siem Reap province. To earn a living, she runs a grocery store from her home and is able to make US$5 per day. She is also aided by two children who work as a taxi driver and a construction worker. Kert N. would like to take out a loan to purchase a motorbike so that she can use it as transportation to purchase grocery products from the market and resupply her store.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike.

loans.name: Pamela

texts.en: Pamela O. is a 57 year old mother of 7 children who sells charcoal in Dunga. Dunga is a small fishing village near Kisumu (and also near where President Obama's grandfather lived). She likes selling charcoal because it is a resource easy to access and everyone needs it. If granted the loan, she will improve her business, which will lead to more money which she says will help her raise her living standard.

loans.use: Charcoal

loans.name: Mok

texts.en: Mok R. is 31 years old and lives with her husband in the Siem Reap province. She is a good housewife, doing house work and cooking for her family members. Her husband is the head of the family and work as a sugar palm seller. On average, he makes US$6 per day. This couple has two school aged children. Mok R. would like to take out a loan to purchase a trailer. The trailer will be attached to a motorbike and will transport coconuts to sell at the market.

loans.use: To purchase a trailer.

loans.name: Soa

texts.en:
Soa K., 45, is a good housewife who lives in the Siem Reap province. Her husband has worked as a housekeeper at the Grand Hotel d’angkor since 2003 and makes $140 per month. Three of their children have a business selling souvenirs and one is a student.

Soa K. would like to take out a loan to purchase a motorbike for her children for commuting to work. This will cut the transport cost that is their main daily expense.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike

loans.name: Siprose Atieno

texts.en:
Siprose A. is a 38-year-old widow and mother of 3. She lives in Kisumu and sells vegetables, purchased from local farmers, at the Oile market.

She is hoping to get a loan because she would like to continue to grow her business, and purchasing more vegetables will help her gain a larger profit.

She says that living with HIV is a challenge while trying to run a business and raise children.

loans.use: Buying vegetables

loans.name: Mann

texts.en:
Mann S., 35, has sold vegetables in the Siem Reap market since 1999. She is able to make around $5 every day. Her husband, pictured here, is a farmer and also raises ducks. On average, he makes about $3 each day. This couple has four children, two of whom are in school while two are too young to attend.

Mann S. would like to ask for a loan so that she can purchase fertilizers to expand her husband’s cultivation.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers

loans.name: Fares

texts.en:
Fares is a 31-year-old man who lives in Nabatieh, southern Lebanon, with his wife and their three children. Fares has owned a barber shop for eight years. He has requested a loan of 1000 US dollars from A. Majmoua in order to purchase tools for his shop. This is the first time that Fares has requested a loan.

Fares is speciA. in his work because he does good haircuts and likes his work. His clients are his friends and neighbors. When he first started his business, he was afraid that his business would fail. In the future, he plans on expanding his business.

loans.use: To purchase tools for his barber shop

loans.name: Sou

texts.en:
Sou S., 20, is married and sells baskets in the Siem Reap province. She started making baskets and selling them at the market in 2007. She is able to make $6 per day. Her husband, pictured here, stays at home and helps her make the baskets.

This couple needs a loan to purchase bamboo so that they can make more baskets to sell to their customers.

loans.use: To purchase bamboo

loans.name: Toch's Group

texts.en:
This group of borrowers consists of four members. Its leader, S., is 49 and has six children: One is married and lives separately, and the other five are attending school. S. is married to Mach, 49, who has a truck he has used to provide transport services to the whole community since 1991. S. owns a sewing machine and has been sewing clothes for the villagers since 2000. She has earned a good income from this business because she is famous for the good job she does.

Recently, S. faces difficulty with transportation. So she is looking a loan to buy a motorbike for her business' transportation.

The other three members are: S., 41, who owns a laundry shop and is looking for a loan to renovate her shop; N., 48, who sells traditional cake in the market and is looking for a loan to rebuild her kitchen; and S., 30, who works in the Apsara's garden and is looking for a loan to buy a motorbike for her work's traveling. They all live in the Siem Reap Province.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for her business' transportation

loans.name: Hassan

texts.en:
Hassan is a 29-year-old man who lives in Nabatieh, southern Lebanon. Hassan has owned a barber shop for ten years. He has requested a loan of 1000 US dollars from Al Majmoua in order to purchase tools for his shop. This is the first time that Hassan has requested a loan.

Hassan is special in his work because he has experience in haircuts. His clients are can be anybody. When he first started his business, he was afraid of the competition. Hassan decided on doing his business because of his experience. In the future, he plans on expanding his business.

loans.use: To purchase tools for his barber shop

loans.name: Debora's Group

texts.en:
Debora has owned a small food vendor store in the Ipagala neighborhood of Dodoma for 2 years. She currently earns an average monthly profit of $215. Every day she works at her business for 12 hours.

She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more food items for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business, get more food for her family and pay school fees for her children.

Debora is married and has four children between the ages of 11 and 17. She also cares for one additional dependent. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group member, Angelina, who also has her own small business in Dodoma.

loans.use: To buy more food items for her business

loans.name: Ly

texts.en: Ly C. L. is 24 years old and lives in the Siem Reap province with her husband. So far, she has no children. She sells fish with her husband in a busy market. On average, they make around USD $3 per day. This couple has requested a loan to purchase more fish to sell at the market.

loans.use: To purchase fish

loans.name: Chhang

texts.en: Chhang O., 62, resides with a married child in the Siem Reap province. She stays at home and looks after her grandchildren. Her daughter, Mit Chong, 30, is the main source of the family’s income. She works in a grocery store, making USD $4 per day. Chhang O. would like to take out a loan to purchase a motorbike so that her son in-law can start a motor-taxi business to help raise the family.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike.

loans.name: Toni

texts.en:
Toni is a 51-year-old man who lives in Tripoli, northern Lebanon, with his wife and their three children. Toni has owned a vegetable shop for ten years. He sells all type of vegetables. Toni has requested a loan of 1200 US dollars from Al Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise and expand his business. This is the first time that Toni has requested a loan.

Toni is special in his work because he is known in his region and clients like going to his shop. His clients are his friends and neighbors. Toni decided on doing his business because he wanted to improve his income. In the future, he plans on expanding his business.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise and expand his vegetable shop

loans.name: Chhet

texts.en: Chhet M., 49, is a widow who lives with three of her children in the Siem Reap province. She is a housewife who stays at home doing housework. She is aided by two children who work at a hotel: one as a cleaner and the other as a waiter. These two children can make USD $6 per day. Mrs. Chhet M. would like to take out a loan to purchase a motorbike for her children to use to commute to work. This will eliminate their main daily expense--the cost of public transportation.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike.

loans.name: Elie

texts.en:
Elie is a 54-year-old man who lives in Tripoli, northern Lebanon. Elie has been working in the sewing business for nine years. Elie has requested a loan of 1000 US dollars from Al Majmoua in order to purchase thread and a new machine for his sewing.

Elie has been a microcredit client for four years now and has always paid on time. His previous loans helped him improve his business and increase his income. His clients are people from his region. When he first started, he had difficulty building networking. Elie decided on doing his business because he likes sewing and wanted to improve his income. In the future, he plans on expanding his business.

loans.use: To purchase thread and a new sewing machine

loans.name: Eunice

texts.en: Eunice is the 30-year-old mother of two children, Nicholas and Evelyn. She sells second-hand clothes in Kisumu. All of the profits of her business go towards raising her children. She plans to use this loan to pay the school fees for her children and to purchase more clothing to sell at the market. She describes her main challenge as "lacking the purchasing power to purchase more goods," which in turn makes it hard for her to keep her family well. She hopes that the users of Kiva will continue to introduce more organizations to Kenya that help promote income-generating activities.

loans.use: To buy used clothes

loans.name: Jestina

texts.en:
Jestina has been a snacks seller in the Mwanjelwa neighborhood of Mbeya for 5 years. She belongs to Kabwe group loan (Group code 2002). She currently earns an average monthly profit of $50. Every day she works at her business for 9 hours.  She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more items for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.  

Jestina is 49 years old, married, and has three children: ages 27, 25,  and 22. She also cares for two additional dependents.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business.

loans.name: Mansour

texts.en:
Mansour is a 37-year-old man who lives in Beirut (the capital of Lebanon) with his wife and their child. Mansour has owned a snack restaurant for four years. He does sandwiches, hot and cold beverages, and also “narguileh” (also known as “shisha” in Egypt). The nargileh is an ancient tradition enjoyed by the people of the Middle East. A tall (or short) water pipe is used to smoke fruit flavored tobacco. Nargileh is enjoyed in cafes across the Middle East, and is beginning to gain popularity in the US, European nations, and other countries.

Mansour has requested a loan of 1000 US dollars from Al Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise for his snack restaurant. This is the first time that Mansour has requested a loan.

Mansour is special in his work because he is known for his good sandwiches. His clients are his friends, neighbors and tourists. When he first started his business, he had difficulty building networking. Mansour decided on doing his business because he always wanted to open a restaurant and work on his own, and because he has experience in the business. In the future, he plans on expanding his business.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise for his snack restaurant

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en: Evelyn A. is twenty-seven years old. She is single and independent. She owns and operates a beauty salon in her neighborhood. Evelyn is a very skillful and talented hair dresser. She does all kinds of hair styles like plaiting, perming, weavons, etc. She believes in efficiency and effectiveness of service; therefore, she wants to use her loan to buy larger quantities of hair products like weavons, pomade, shampoo, activators, etc. to avoid shortages and poor service. She is a member of the community group called Fine Trust Group.
